unnormalised: Heart health in India is becoming a serious concern, you know? It's not just an "uncle" disease anymore. We’re seeing younger and younger people getting diagnosed with all sorts of cardiac problems. Gotta get ourselves checked out more often, I think. Dr. Rajesh at AIIMS says lifestyle changes are key, but let's be real, easier said than done with all the stress these days, no?

Doctor Rajesh at A-I-I-M-S says lifestyle changes are key, but let's be real, easier said than done with all the stress these days, no?

unnormalised: One of the biggest issues is the rising prevalence of heart attacks, or MIs as they call 'em in the medical world. These things can strike anyone, anytime. I read a report that mentioned a 25% increase in heart attacks among individuals under 40 yrs old. The usual suspects are there – smoking, high cholesterol (anything above 200 mg/dL is risky!), and lack of exercise. And don't even get me started on all that delicious but unhealthy street food!
normalised: One of the biggest issues is the rising prevalence of heart attacks, or M-I-s as they call 'em in the medical world. These things can strike anyone, anytime. I read a report that mentioned a twenty five percent increase in heart attacks among individuals under forty years old. The usual suspects are there – smoking, high cholesterol (anything above two hundred milligrams per D-L is risky!), and lack of exercise. And don't even get me started on all that delicious but unhealthy street food!

unnormalised: Then there’s the whole issue of heart failure. Apparently, it's more common than we think. It's when the heart can't pump blood properly. Symptoms include breathlessness, swelling in the legs, and fatigue. My grandpa had it, and he was on all sorts of meds – ACE inhibitors, beta-blockers, and diuretics. He visited Dr. Kapoor every month for checkups at the hospital.

unnormalised: Plus, there's atrial fibrillation, or AFib, which causes an irregular heartbeat. That can lead to strokes, which are scary stuff. A friend of mine was diagnosed with AFib at the age of 35. He was put on anticoagulants to prevent blood clots. He goes for regular ECGs, and they monitor his heart rate using a fancy smartwatch thingy.
normalised: Plus, there's atrial fibrillation, or A-Fib, which causes an irregular heartbeat. That can lead to strokes, which are scary stuff. A friend of mine was diagnosed with A-Fib at the age of thirty five. He was put on anticoagulants to prevent blood clots. He goes for regular E-C-G-s, and they monitor his heart rate using a fancy smartwatch thingy.

unnormalised: And let's not forget about congenital heart defects – problems that babies are born with. These can range from minor issues to serious conditions requiring surgery. I heard a story about a newborn at CMC Vellore needing immediate surgery to fix a heart defect. Docs are doing some amazing things these days, no?

unnormalised: So, what's the takeaway? Get regular check-ups, especially if you have a family history of heart disease. Eat healthy (less butter chicken, more veggies!), exercise regularly (even just a brisk walk every day helps!), and manage your stress levels. And hey, if you feel something's not right, don't delay! See a cardiologist ASAP. Your heart will thank you for it!
